randomized controlled trial.reasoning: A randomized controlled trial is a specific experimental method used to determine the effects of the resistance training interventions on arterial stiffness by randomly assigning participants to different groups.
passages: This study sought to determine the association between 2 common resistance training models and indices of arterial stiffness.
Using a randomized controlled trial with validated measurements of arterial stiffness

resistance training.reasoning: Resistance training refers to the specific intervention implemented in the study, involving different training models to assess their effects on arterial stiffness.
passages: Some reports indicate that resistance training increases indices of arterial stiffness, whereas others report no association.
Subjects randomized to the resistance training groups were required to perform whole-body strength training exercises 3-5 days a week for 12 weeks.

validated measurements.reasoning: Validated measurements refer to the specific techniques employed to assess arterial stiffness, ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the data collected.
passages: Using a randomized controlled trial with validated measurements of arterial stiffness

exercise regimen.reasoning: The exercise regimen outlines the specific procedures and protocols followed during the resistance training intervention, detailing how the training was structured.
passages: The exercise regimen consisted of 2-3 sets of 3-8 repetitions (80-90% of 1 repetition maximum [1RM]) for the HI group and 3-4 sets of 10-15 repetitions (50-70% of 1RM) for the HV group.
